Comment: This puzzle is educational and serves as a straightforward exercise for the minimax algorithm.

âœ… Approved the contribution.
Comment: Well thougth & quite original for minimax learning! Gratz for the work ;)

Very entertaining. Not completed yet, but my assumption is that the single play of the base position is based on heuristics (e.g. play a win if possible,  avoid a loose if required,  play a move that allow more possible wins, etc...).  Can you please clarify in the narrative if it's the case or if some minmax is required ?  
Also, validator 6 and 9  fail whereas the corresponding test case works.  This situation is usually quite frustrating.  Is it possible to think of a test case that is less probable to be green when the validator is red ?

Goal
* Please briefly explain the winning/losing/draw conditions.

* Please define "the best move".

* The phrase "disambiguate edge cases" is unclear. Is it essential to the task? Can we remove it?

Output
* The term "final" seems to imply that either a player has already won or the board is full. Please revise the wording. My understanding is that the output should be either the same board as the input or the board state after the engine player makes the best move.

Cases
* Validator 3 violates the constraint.

* I haven't fully reviewed the cases yet. I'll do so after additional cases have been added.

Thanks.
Good catch on Validator 3 :) I have updated the sections accordingly.

Hey @Chris27, thank you for the comment.

Regarding your first question, I've specified in the problem statement that the engine should always play the best possible move: "On its turn, the engine must choose the move that maximizes its chance of winning, or forces a draw, or delays a loss. In a winning position, the engine should choose the move that wins in the fewest number of turns. Likewise, in a losing position, the engine should choose the move that loses in the most number of turns." It is up to you to choose a heuristic-based or minmax-based method, or any other method, to solve the problem.

Regarding Validators 6 and 9, I don't see why these validators should fail. For Validator 6, there are only two winning moves (either top-right or bottom-left corner), and their cell values acts as the tie-breaker. Similarly, for Validator 9, both valid moves lose, but their cell values ultimately lead you to choose the top-right corner. The puzzle has been set up this way to ensure a deterministic output.
I have also added the rest of the test cases. Not sure if the Medium difficulty is suitable for this puzzle; I would say it's an easy Medium.

Happy to help ðŸ™‚

Output
* The current wording implicitly assumes that a move is always made. Consider adding a clarification to the end:

If the game is already over, output the board unchanged.

Difficulty
* I would classify this puzzle as Medium. For comparison,
  â€¢ Easy: Involves loops, conditions and basic string manipulation.
  â€¢ Medium: Involves algorithms such as BFS, DFS and recursion.
  â€¢ This puzzle: Implementing Minimax is more complex than any of the above, though it doesn't quite reach the Hard level.

Cases
* Validator 9 violates the constraint.

* Consider splitting pair 10 into two separate pairs:
  â€¢ One where [[engine]] is "O", and the first X can be placed anywhere on the board.
  â€¢ Another where [[engine]] is "X" and the board is empty (and test = validator).

Thanks.
Nice, fixed all the outstanding issues. Thanks!
